In order to investigate the prospects of a cosmopolitan world order, the central features of each of the cosmopolitan agendas are outlined, and then possible changes within the international system, which might indicate a movement towards them, are isolated. The resulting five criteria upon which analysis is based are: identification with a cosmopolitan community; institutional changes; global civil society; the enhancement of autonomy; and FfD’s influence in the international order. The different writers examined in this investigation have different conceptions of how each of these criteria will be established. At the same time, each value has only a limited ability to predict the likelihood of future changes. A central aspect of the investigation is a comparison between the results identified using each interpretation of cosmopolitanism. As such, it is found that results were largely determined by the method of interpretation employed. Overall, the work of Bohman (1996, 1999) and Dryzek (1999) was found to best reflect the empirical evidence from FfD.
